title: supporting Emacs universal-argument (c-u by default)
body:
Before I start digging into how to implement the Emacs universal-argument (c-u), which none of the Emacs packages support and which is painful to lose after 40+ years of Emacs finger habits, including in the macOS built-in text editing support --

http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/emacs/Arguments.html

-- it seems to me it would need in-built support in VSCode to work, since it introduces the notion of repeating a following command _n_ times (where the argument is _n_, either implied or typed), whether built-in or added by an extension.

Is there any hope that this could be implemented entirely in an extension? I.e., is there any way for an extension to capture and map the next keyboard command, however invoked, and run it multiple times?

title: Provide license field for all submodules
body:
it will avoid several warnings during build

for instance:
```
warning ..\package.json: No license field
warning code-oss-dev-build@1.0.0: No license field
warning php-language-features@1.0.0: No license field
```

title: Split JSON settings editor discussion issue
body:
So as you can see here:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45121609/52544545-bb849380-2db1-11e9-9d02-f22b8377243a.png)

when I open my `settings.json` file I don't have it split up. Before updating whenever I opened `settings.json` I had all the settings on the left hand side and those changed by me on the right hand side. Now I only have the thing, which was previously on the right.

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.31.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open settings
2. Click `{}` to open `settings.json`

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Draw the status bar's background in different colors (eg red, yellow) if the program has errors/warnings
body:
Hi! I've just started using VS Code this week. I've done several searches for this feature or a similar feature request and haven't found anything, please let me know if I've missed something.

I think that it should be possible for themes to affect the status bar's background color if the program has an error or warning. https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/theme-color#status-bar-colors has a list of properties that can be used to affect the status bar's color, but as far as I can tell, none of these properties allow me to accomplish this.

If the program in the current editor window has an error, I want my theme to be able to color the status bar red. If the program has a warning, I want my theme to be able to color the status bar yellow. If there are both, I think that the error state should take priority, and so the status bar should use my red background color.

Does something like this exist and I've just missed it?

Thank you! :)

title: Have a more comfortable cursor/scroll position on undo
body: When I hit undo and the scroll changes, the cursor is set to the very top, making it hard to quickly see relevant code, making me have to scroll up a bit. Would be better in my opinion if it scrolled somewhere near the middle.

title: allow global flag to have ALL new extensions be disabled by default

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
This is mainly for multi-project (mult-workspace) polyglot development.
I have workspaces that need 5 extensions, others 10 different others, etc.
Being esp. dev ops engineer you have to mess with code written in plethora of languages.

I know a developer (selfless ;)) can make the extension disabled after installation, BUT Relying on extension developer be selfless, and to make the extension disabled by default is not going to work:
as a developer I would WANT to enable the extension. I want it to be used.

So what we should have is a global flag "enable installed extensions".

When user sets it to "False", the new extensions will not be enabled post installation.

Benefits of this "policy" would be:
1. snappy experience
2. less extension A vs. extension B conflicts
3. less meddling (it is easier to enable 7 extension for a new project than to disable 40)

IF I am missing an existing feature, please tell me.

Thanks!

title: Reordering members through outline view
body:
Hi,

I would like to be able to drag and drop contents in the outline view. This would be useful for example to rearrange xml files or class methods.

title: Explorer will not open anymore using shortcut if release notes is already shown
body: Issue Type: Bug 1. Open some project 2. Show release notes, typing: `cmd+p` > Show release notes 3. Toggle explorer pressing once, typing: `cmd+b` 4. Now, try to toggle the explorer more times and you will see (after the third pressing) that the explorer will not open anymore. __VS Code version:__ Code 1.31.0 (7c66f58312b48ed8ca4e387ebd9ffe9605332caa, 2019-02-05T22:32:14.164Z) __OS version:__ Darwin x64 18.2.0

title: Support comments in UI editors (settings and keyboard shortcuts)
Tab press in search panel should navigate to next text field
body:
When pressing tab in the search panel with CTRL+SHIFT+F, I should be able to:

1. enter some text in the 'search' field
2. press tab
3. enter some text in the 'files to include' field
4. press enter.

But it is necessary to press tab 5(!) times to get from the 'search' field to the 'files to include' field.

According to #34676 this was fixed in 1.25, but I'm running version 1.31.0 and I still see the issue.

title: Enlarge scroll bar button when mouse near by
body:
This issue is for a feature request - that the scroll bar button scales to 2.0 or so whenever the mouse button gets near it. Currently I have Visual Studio Code set to Zoom out the entire interface so I can fit more on the screen. The only problem with that is that the scroll bars also zoom and become tiny and hard to grab.

It would be great if the scroll bar got big whenever the mouse got near. I think this can be done with `transform: scale` but there may need to be more work done because the button goes past the top and bottom.

I have included a screenshot of what it might look like:

![vscode-enlarge-scrollbar](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1364432/52440317-9999c100-2ad2-11e9-820a-5f0db91ca4dd.gif)

title: VSCode version distribution dashboard for extension authors
body:
It would be nice to have a regularly-updated published breakdown of the pct of active vscode installs by stable version, similar to Android's [Platform Version Distribution Dashboard](https://developer.android.com/about/dashboards/#Platform).

This would give extension authors information on which versions of the extension api to support at a given point in time.

Thanks!

title: Pin source control header elements when tree horizontal scroll enabled

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
With version 1.31, horizontal scroll is now enabled for more trees and lists, including the source control view.  While this is nice, the buttons are all the way at the end, which is not ideal when there are long filenames or deeply nested files which go out of the view and require scrolling.  
Would it be possible to have the on-hover buttons for the actions (discard changes, stage changes, etc) to be fixed to the current view similar to the explorer buttons?  It is harder to use the source control as is.

It is great to see that task configurations now allow the specification of terminal group (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/47265) - works well from my initial testing. title: Git: Support git worktrees in workspace

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
```
$ mkdir repro
$ cd repro
$ mkdir example1
$ cd example1
$ git init; echo "hello" > world.txt; git add world.txt; git commit -m "init";
$ git worktree add ../example1branchA
$ git worktree add ../example1branchB
$ cd ..

$ mkdir example2
$ cd example2
$ git init; echo "hello" > world.txt; git add world.txt; git commit -m "init";
$ cd ..
```
Scenario:
1. Open `repro` directory in VS Code
2. Go to Git tab.

**Expected:** "Source Control Providers" lists Git repos.
  * `example1`
  * `example1branchA`
  * `example1branchB`
  * `example2`

**Actual:** "Source Control Providers" lists Git repos.
 * `example1`
 * `example2`

I sometimes will have lots of branches checked out in parallel on huge repos that I can't afford to clone multiple times. I would also like to be able to use VS Code's source control functionality with these checkouts all the same.

Thanks! and thanks for Code!

title: Latest update broke extensions  1.31.0 Mac
body: - VSCode Version: Version 1.31.0 (1.31.0) - OS Version: MacOS Mojave I had an update notification pop up which I did not realize it was going to run when I closed my editor and then re-opened it shortly after. Since the latest released up, all my extensions will not run and on start up i get "Extension host terminated unexpectedly." No matter how many times I click restart extension host it continues showing the failed message. To clarify when this happened to me I was using 1.30 and restarted VSCode got the prompt for the January Changes skimmed it and then started noticing that no plugins were working. - Restarted a few times and got the screenshotted prompt above. - Tried restarted my laptop and then getting back in vscode - Checked if there was another update after to fix it - Then decided to re-install vscode while using another editor/terminal to ssh into a server to deploy the project I was working on when this happened Since the re-install I do believe all my extensions are working as expect and do not believe I removed any. Most of my extensions are Larave, PHP, 1 or 2 Python, couple RoR, and then some Node/angular.

title: New explorer: allow to filter by path

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
This would be an amazing feature to have: allow to type a path (relative) which makes the file explorer narrow down by exactly that path, e.g.:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/900690/52353886-b4672980-2a2f-11e9-96b2-9ce10741df45.png)

Maybe trees should be allowed to opt into this behaviour which is, when you type a `/` or `\` as part of the filter, it also respects the resource path of the element if it has any.

//cc @joaomoreno
